verses.text: Surely vain \add are\add* all men by nature, who are ignorant of God, and could not out of the good \add things\add* that are seen know him that is: neither by considering the works did they acknowledge the workmaster;
but deemed either fire, or wind, or the swift air, or the circle of the stars, or the violent water, or the lights of heaven, \add to be\add* the gods which govern the world.
With whose beauty if they being delighted took them \add to be\add* gods; let them know how much better the Lord of them is: for the first Author of beauty hath created them.
But if they were astonished at \add their\add* power and virtue, let them understand by them, how much mightier he is that made them.
For by the greatness and beauty of the creatures proportionably the Maker of them is seen.
But yet for this \add they\add* are the less to be blamed: for they peradventure err, seeking God, and desirous to find \add him\add*.
For being conversant in his works they search \add him\add* diligently, and believe \add their\add* sight: because the \add things are\add* beautiful that are seen.
Howbeit neither \add are\add* they to be pardoned.
For if they were able to know so much, that they could aim at the world; how did they not sooner find out the Lord thereof?

But miserable \add are\add* they, and in dead \add things is\add* their hope, who called \add them\add* gods, \add which are\add* the works of men’s hands, gold and silver, to shew art in, and resemblances of beasts, or a stone good for nothing, the work of an ancient hand.

Now a carpenter that felleth timber, after he hath sawn down a tree meet for the purpose, and taken off all the bark skilfully round about, and hath wrought \add it\add* handsomely, and made a vessel \add thereof\add* fit for the service of \add man’s\add* life;
and after spending the refuse of \add his\add* work to dress \add his\add* meat, hath filled himself;

And taking the \add very\add* refuse among those, which served to no use, \add being\add* a crooked piece of wood, and full of knots, hath carved \add it\add* diligently, when he had nothing else to do, and formed it by the skill of \add his\add* understanding, and fashioned it to the image of a man;
or made it like some vile beast, laying \add it\add* over with vermilion, and with paint colouring it red, and covering every spot therein;
and when he had made a convenient room for it, set it in a wall, and made \add it\add* fast with iron:
for he provided for it that it might not fall, knowing that it was unable to help itself; for it is an image, and hath need of help:
then maketh he prayer for \add his\add* goods, for his wife and children, and is not ashamed to speak to \add that which hath\add* no life.

For health he calleth upon \add that which is\add* weak: for life prayeth to \add that which is\add* dead: for aid humbly beseecheth that which hath least means to help: and for a good journey \add he asketh of\add* that which cannot set a foot forward:
and for gaining and getting, and \add for\add* good success of his hands, asketh ability to do of him, \add that\add* is most unable to do any thing.
